stories_content_0: The world's biggest oil and gas companies are cutting spending this year following a collapse in oil prices driven by a slump in demand because of the coronavirus crisis and a price war between top exporters Saudi Arabia and Russia.
stories_content_1: The world's biggest maker of medical gloves is grappling with a serious shortage of workers as it tries to meet a huge surge in demand as countries such as the United States run out of personal protective gear due to the coronavirus outbreak.
stories_content_2: Driving to work at his factory to the west of London last week, designer Steve Brooks had coronavirus on his mind. What could he make that would let him open a door without touching the handle?

stories_content_5: China's ports and shipping firms are bracing for a second wave of supply chain disruptions that may be deeper and more prolonged than during the country's coronavirus lockdown as the global spread of the virus chokes off international demand.

main_title: U.S. weekly jobless claims seen at record high: again
main_content: The number of Americans filing claims for unemployment benefits likely shot to a record high for a second week in a row as more jurisdictions enforced stay-at-home measures to curb the coronavirus pandemic, which economists say has pushed the economy into recession.

stories_content_5: U.S. stock index futures fell on Friday, with investors awaiting data on non-farm payrolls and business activity to assess the extent of the economic hit from the coronavirus.

main_title: Coronavirus depresses U.S. payrolls, more job losses coming
main_content: The U.S. economy shed 701,000 jobs in March, abruptly ending a historic 113 straight months of employment growth as stringent measures to control the novel coronavirus outbreak shuttered businesses and factories, confirming a recession is underway.

stories_content_5: It is illegal for oil producers to meet to discuss pushing up oil prices under U.S. antitrust law, but perfectly legal if state regulators or the federal government set lower production levels for them, U.S. antitrust experts said on Friday.

main_title: How one Silicon Valley factory keeps running in the age of coronavirus

main_title: Futures jump on hopes of slowdown in coronavirus cases

main_title: Coronavirus hopes propel stocks, euro higher
main_content: World stock markets enjoyed a second day of sharp gains on Tuesday as signs of progress against the coronavirus in both Europe and the United States and more liberal helpings of stimulus kept investors charging back in.

stories_content_5: Oil prices clawed their way into positive territory on Tuesday as hopes that the world's biggest producers will agree to cut output outweighed analyst fears that a global recession in the wake of the coronavirus crisis could be deeper than expected.

main_title: Wobbly U.S. fiscal response could deepen coronavirus recession
main_content: The U.S. government's massive effort to nurse the economy through the coronavirus crisis was billed as a send-money-and-don't-sweat-the-details flood of cash to people and businesses in a $22 trillion system that has ground to a halt.

stories_content_5: World stocks turned negative on Wednesday as the coronavirus death toll mounted and euro zone finance ministers failed to agree a rescue package to help economies recover from the impact of the outbreak.

main_title: Fed rolls out $2.3 trillion to backstop "Main Street," local governments
main_content: The U.S. Federal Reserve on Thursday rolled out a broad, $2.3 trillion effort to bolster local governments and small and mid-sized businesses in its latest move to keep the U.S. economy intact as the country battles the coronavirus pandemic.

main_title: High U.S. unemployment, 2.5 million jobs lost through 2021: survey
main_content: After a widely expected and sharp drop in the U.S. economy over the next three months, a panel of top business economists sees high joblessness persisting for more than a year in an outcome that would douse hopes for a quick, post-pandemic return to normal.

main_content: U.S. consumer prices fell by the most in more than five years in March and further decreases are likely as the novel coronavirus outbreak suppresses demand for some goods and services, offsetting price increases related to shortages resulting from disruptions to the supply chain.

main_content: Big U.S. banks made a pretty penny in trading during the first quarter as the coronavirus pandemic caused wild market swings, analysts said, but those gains will likely be overshadowed by declines in other businesses and a bleak outlook for the rest of the year.

stories_content_1: Amazon will begin to put new grocery delivery customers on a wait list and curtail shopping hours at some Whole Foods stores to prioritize orders from existing customers buying food online during the coronavirus outbreak, the company said on Sunday.
stories_content_2: Global equities weakened on Monday as investors braced for more indications of economic damage from the coronavirus pandemic while oil prices rose in choppy trade following a landmark deal by OPEC and its allies to cut output.
stories_content_3: Pou Chen Corp , the world's largest manufacturer of branded athletic and casual footwear for the likes of Nike  and Adidas , has been ordered to suspend production at its Pouyuen Vietnam business over COVID-19 concerns, Vietnamese state media reported on Monday.
stories_content_4: Billionaire Richard Branson's space tourism company Virgin Galactic Holdings Inc  will keep running as a critical infrastructure business, even as many U.S. states in which it operates have mandated business closures during the coronavirus outbreak.
stories_content_5: Softbank Group Corp  said on Monday it expects its $100 billion Vision Fund to book a loss of 1.8 trillion yen ($16.5 billion) in the financial year ended March due to the deteriorating performance of its tech bets.

main_title: Pandemic survival plans: U.S. businesses scramble to conserve cash, boost liquidity
main_content: Charlie Straface, president of Norwegian aluminum maker Norsk Hydro's North American extrusion operations, convenes a coronavirus task force every other day to draw up cost-cutting measures to offset declining revenues and protect the unit's cash balance during the economic slump related to the outbreak.

stories_content_0: U.S. stock markets opened more than 1% higher on Tuesday as the quarterly earnings season kicked off with JPMorgan and Johnson & Johnson giving a first glimpse of the coronavirus outbreak's impact on corporate America.

stories_content_2: The ten U.S. states coordinating plans separately from the White House to reopen businesses shut by the coronavirus are responsible for an outsized proportion of the U.S. economy.
stories_content_3: Bombardier Inc  said on Tuesday it plans to resume production at some of its facilities in the United Kingdom, which had been halted in March due to government-mandated social distancing to battle the coronavirus pandemic.
stories_content_4: Hyundai Motor Co's  Czech car plant was the first in the central European country to get back to work on Tuesday after a three-week outage, potentially easing some of the strain on the hard-hit economy.
stories_content_5: Delta Air Lines  has taken over an order worth roughly $3 billion at list prices for 10 Airbus  A350 jetliners from Latam Airlines Group ), two industry sources said.

main_title: Bank of America profit nearly halves as loan loss provisions soar

main_title: U.S. weekly jobless claims highlight economic carnage from coronavirus

stories_content_5: Delivery business DHL  is struggling to cope with a flood of parcels from online purchases due to the coronavirus crisis, forcing it to cut back extra collections from retailers in Germany, parent company Deutsche Post said on Thursday.

main_content: The magnitude of how damaged the energy industry is came into full view on April 20 when the benchmark price of U.S. oil futures , which had never dropped below $10 a barrel in its nearly 40-year history, plunged to a previously unthinkable minus $38 a barrel.

stories_title_0: Special Report: Countries, companies risk billions in race for coronavirus vaccine
stories_title_1: Wall Street Week Ahead: Spotlight falls on 'dividend aristocrats' after market tumult
stories_title_2: U.S. airlines receive extra $9.5 billion in payroll support: U.S. Treasury
stories_title_3: Virgin Atlantic says still talking with UK government on coronavirus funds
stories_title_4: Daimler says China business picks up again: report
stories_title_5: Cash is king as U.S. quarterly reporting season gains steam
stories_content_0: By Julie Steenhuysen, Peter Eisler, Allison Martell and Stephanie Nebehay
stories_content_1: Companies across a range of industries are slashing or suspending dividends to cope with the economic fallout from the coronavirus outbreak, complicating the stock selection process for money managers eager to buttress their portfolios with a steady stream of income.
stories_content_2: The U.S. Treasury Department said on Saturday it has released $9.5 billion in additional funds from the Payroll Support Program to U.S. air carriers, bringing to $12.4 billion the total provided to the airline sector hit hard by the coronavirus pandemic.
stories_content_3: Virgin Atlantic is still talking with the British government about a bailout package to cope with the devastating effects of the coronavirus outbreak on travel as well as focusing on private sector funding, a company spokeswoman told Reuters.
stories_content_4: Mercedes-Benz maker Daimler  has seen business stabilise in China after the country ended coronavirus lockdowns, a senior manager at the German carmaker told a newspaper on Sunday.
stories_content_5: With the U.S. quarterly earnings season picking up steam this week, investors have caught a glimpse of how companies are weathering the coronavirus outbreak, including the strength of their balance sheets.

main_title: Exclusive: Investors to challenge Neiman Marcus bankruptcy loan, push for sale - sources
main_content: An investor group that comprises investment firm Mudrick Capital Management LP and Daniel Loeb's hedge fund Third Point LLC plans to challenge a $600 million financing package that Neiman Marcus Group has lined up for its looming bankruptcy, and will push the U.S. department store operator to sell itself, people familiar with the matter said on Sunday.

stories_title_0: Futures gain as more states prepare to ease lockdowns
stories_title_1: Explainer: U.S. payroll protection program: What has changed in round two?
stories_title_2: GE's coronavirus troubles likely to hit power business, not just aviation
stories_title_3: Broadcom offers to scrap exclusivity deals to end EU antitrust probe
stories_title_4: Alibaba demotes top executive after probe into behaviour: source
stories_title_5: Scrutiny mounts on China's Luckin Coffee as market regulator inspects
stories_content_0: U.S. stock index futures rose on Monday as more states looked set to lift coronavirus-induced curbs, with investors also turning to quarterly earnings reports from marquee companies including Apple and Microsoft later this week.
stories_content_1: The Small Business Administration (SBA) on Monday will release $310 billion in funds for the second round of its program that aims to help small businesses hurt by the novel coronavirus disruption to cover their payroll costs.
stories_content_2: Quarantines and lockdowns at large U.S. power plants are threatening to squeeze a multibillion-dollar slice of revenue that General Electric Co  is counting on to help lift profits.
stories_content_3: U.S. chipmaker Broadcom has offered to settle an EU antitrust investigation into its exclusivity deals with TV and modem makers, EU antitrust regulators said on Monday, a move that would stave off a possible hefty fine.
stories_content_4: Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba Group Holding Ltd  has demoted Jiang Fan, one of its most senior executives, after an internal investigation into allegations of improper behaviour, according to a person familiar with the matter.
stories_content_5: China's top market regulator has launched an inspection into Luckin Coffee , joining the country's securities watchdog in doing so as the coffee chain comes under scrutiny for fabricating millions of dollars worth of sales deals.

main_title: Ford investors keen for details on when automaker will restart U.S. operations
main_content: Investors already know how the coronavirus outbreak has hurt Ford Motor Co's  bottom line, so when the automaker releases first-quarter results on Tuesday they will focus on how and when Ford plans to restart North American operations.

stories_title_0: Futures jump with focus on earnings, easing of lockdowns
stories_title_1: Merck profit beats, coronavirus uncertainty weighs on forecast
stories_title_2: Remote work revenue could help Microsoft offset coronavirus impacts, analysts say
stories_title_3: Lufthansa may seek creditor protection alongside Berlin rescue talks
stories_title_4: PepsiCo beats revenue estimates but scraps forecast over virus crisis
stories_title_5: Harley-Davidson cuts dividend payout, suspends share buybacks
stories_content_0: U.S. stock index futures rose on Tuesday after a round of quarterly earnings reports brought upbeat signs from Pfizer and respiratory mask-maker 3M for investors increasingly hopeful of a relaunch of business across the economy.
stories_content_1: Merck & Co Inc  beat analysts' estimates for quarterly profit on Tuesday on strong demand for its blockbuster cancer drug, Keytruda, but expects coronavirus-led lockdowns to weigh on the treatment's sales in the next few quarters.
stories_content_2: When Microsoft Corp reports earnings on Wednesday, analysts expect some areas of its business to take a hit from the novel coronavirus pandemic, with lower-than-expected sales in areas like advertising on its LinkedIn social network.
stories_content_3: Lufthansa might seek some form of protection from creditors while talking to the Berlin government about a 9 billion euro ($9.76 billion) rescue package, a company source said on Tuesday after government and airline sources said talks on a deal were continuing.
stories_content_4: PepsiCo Inc  beat first quarter revenue estimates, but ditched its full-year forecast on Tuesday, citing uncertainty around the globe due to the novel coronavirus pandemic.
stories_content_5: Harley-Davidson Inc  cut its quarterly dividend to just 2 cents and suspended share buybacks on Tuesday to boost its cash reserves even as it reported a smaller-than-expected decline in quarterly profit.

main_title: Corona what? Tesla retail investors appear unfazed by virus impact
main_content: When Tesla Inc reports first-quarter results after the bell on Wednesday, many individual shareholders will not be looking for details on the subject that drives most conversations: the effect of the novel coronavirus pandemic.

stories_title_0: Coronavirus hammered U.S. economy in first quarter
stories_title_1: Boeing to cut workforce by 10% and reduce 787 production due to pandemic
stories_title_2: Samsung's phone fortunes wane as COVID-19 hits 5G phones in Europe and U.S.
stories_title_3: U.S. insurers want taxpayers to back pandemic coverage for businesses
stories_title_4: Minority businesses worry they are locked out of payroll lending program
stories_title_5: Boeing to cut staff by 10% amid coronavirus pandemic
stories_content_0: The U.S. economy contracted in the first quarter at its sharpest pace since the Great Recession as stringent measures to slow the spread of the novel coronavirus almost shut down the country, ending the longest expansion in the nation's history.
stories_content_1: Boeing Co  said on Wednesday it would cut its workforce by about 10% and further reduce 787 Dreamliner production after reporting a loss for the second straight quarter as the coronavirus pandemic hits global travel demand.
stories_content_2: When the coronavirus outbreak in China disrupted global smartphone production in February, Samsung looked set to weather the crisis better than most thanks to its limited exposure there and launches of pricey 5G phones. Its fortunes are reversing.
stories_content_3: The U.S. insurance industry is promoting the idea of an insurance plan backed by the federal government that would help businesses that in the future suffer losses from a pandemic, people familiar with the effort told Reuters.
stories_content_4: As the government issues a second round of aid for small business owners, some U.S. senators, community banking groups and minority-owned banks said they are worried businesses owned by people of color may miss out on receiving much-needed loans.
stories_content_5: Boeing Co  CEO Dave Calhoun told employees on Wednesday that the largest U.S. planemaker is reducing the size of its workforce by about 10% amid a steep fall in travel demand due to the coronavirus pandemic.

main_title: 'W-shaped' recovery may be too optimistic, Fed's Powell suggests
main_content: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell has sketched out an altogether bumpier ride for the U.S. economy than many are predicting - one that sees business activity stop and start for months to come, until an effective treatment or vaccine for the novel coronavirus can be found.

stories_title_0: McDonald's profit slides as restaurants limit services
stories_title_1: Comcast first-quarter broadband growth tops views, coronavirus hurts advertising
stories_title_2: Twitter tops sales estimates, sees rebound from Asia's eased coronavirus rules
stories_title_3: ConocoPhillips reports 58% fall in quarterly profit
stories_title_4: Lufthansa, unions: we want to keep as many jobs as possible
stories_title_5: Airbus in talks with French state, no liquidity concerns at present, says CEO
stories_content_0: McDonald's Corp  reported a 16.7% slide in quarterly profit on Thursday as most of its restaurants across the globe limited their services to deliveries and take-aways to halt the spread of the coronavirus pandemic.
stories_content_1: Comcast Corp  on Thursday reported its best quarter of broadband net additions in 12 years, but revenue fell shy of Wall Street's estimate as the coronavirus pandemic hurt advertising.
stories_content_2: Twitter Inc  on Thursday said that its ads sales had slightly rebounded in Asia after a plunge due to the coronavirus outbreak and that it had accelerated work on tools to attract key advertisers, becoming the latest tech company to report a lighter blow from the pandemic than forecast.
stories_content_3: U.S. oil and gas company ConocoPhillips reported a 58% plunge in adjusted quarterly profit on Thursday, weighed down by lower output and an unprecedented plunge in crude prices.
stories_content_4: Lufthansa and unions representing much of its staff told the German government that their joint top priorities were to maintain the airline's competitiveness after the coronavirus crisis and preserve as many jobs as possible.
stories_content_5: European planemaker Airbus  is in talks with the French state regarding possible support for aircraft deliveries, even though it has no liquidity problems at present, Airbus Chief Executive Guillaume Faury said on Thursday.
